key_questions.Who are the distinct types of users (e.g: Game Masters (GMs) who run role-playing game sessions using the Foundry Virtual Tabletop system. These are the primary users who need to manage multiple minion tokens during combat encounters.
key_questions.What are the key goals, behaviors, or de: GMs want to efficiently manage groups of minions (mobs) during combat without having to individually click on every minion token. They want to: (1) Group minions into mobs that act together, (2) Apply strategies to mobs (attack most powerful target, attack weakest target, defend leader, attack most damaged), (3) Control mobs with single actions rather than individual minion actions.
key_questions.Who are the primary users or stakeholder: Game Masters using Foundry Virtual Tabletop system for running role-playing game sessions, particularly those managing combat encounters with multiple minion tokens.
key_questions.What is the first thing users will try t: Create a mob by grouping existing minion tokens together, then apply a strategy to that mob so all minions in the mob perform coordinated actions.
key_questions.What problems, inefficiencies, or workar: The current problem is that GMs must click on every individual minion token to make them perform actions during combat. This is time-consuming and tedious when managing many minions. The workaround being eliminated is manual, repetitive clicking on each minion token individually.
key_questions.Where are users currently struggling, ge: Users struggle during combat encounters when they have multiple minion tokens on the virtual tabletop. They get stuck having to manually select and command each minion individually, causing delays in gameplay flow and making combat management cumbersome.
key_questions.What other systems, data sources, or too: The capability must integrate with Foundry Virtual Tabletop system. It needs to interact with: (1) Actor system (for minion tokens and mob templates), (2) Token system (for selecting and grouping tokens), (3) Combat system (for executing attacks and movements), (4) Range/movement system (for determining valid targets and movement requirements), (5) Area attack system (for area-based attacks).
key_questions.What are the key behaviors or integratio: Key integration points: (1) Mob creation depends on Actor system to identify minion actors, (2) Token selection depends on Foundry's token system to group tokens into mobs, (3) Strategy execution depends on Combat system to determine valid targets and execute attacks, (4) Target selection strategies (attack most powerful, weakest, most damaged) depend on Combat system to evaluate target states, (5) Movement and range calculations depend on Foundry's spatial/range system, (6) Area attacks depend on Foundry's area effect system.
key_questions.What is the business domain we are model: Virtual Tabletop Game Management - specifically combat encounter management for role-playing games, focusing on minion and mob coordination within the Foundry Virtual Tabletop system.
key_questions.What are the core business concepts and: Core concepts: (1) Minion - individual game entity/token that can be controlled, (2) Mob - collection of minions that act together as a coordinated group, (3) Strategy - behavioral rules that determine how a mob selects targets and performs actions (e.g., attack most powerful target, attack weakest target, defend leader, attack most damaged), (4) Target Selection - process of choosing which entities to attack based on strategy rules, (5) Actor - Foundry system entity representing a game character/creature, (6) Token - visual representation of an actor on the virtual tabletop. Relationships: Mobs contain multiple Minions, Mobs have Strategies, Strategies determine Target Selection behavior, Minions are Actors represented as Tokens.
key_questions.What are the distinct sub-domains or bus: Sub-domains: (1) Mob Management - creating, editing, grouping, and managing mobs, (2) Strategy Management - defining and applying strategies to mobs, (3) Target Selection - determining targets based on strategy rules (most powerful, weakest, most damaged, defend leader), (4) Combat Execution - performing coordinated actions (attacks, movements, area attacks) for all minions in a mob, (5) Integration with Foundry - working within Foundry's actor, token, combat, and range systems.
key_questions.What are the boundaries between differen: Boundaries: (1) Mob Management is separate from individual minion control (mobs act as groups, not individuals), (2) Strategy rules are separate from combat execution (strategies determine what to do, combat system executes how to do it), (3) Target selection logic is separate from actual attack execution, (4) Mob functionality is separate from Foundry's core systems but depends on them, (5) Mob templates (for spawning) are separate from runtime mob instances.
key_questions.What domain events occur in this busines: Domain events: (1) Mob Created - when minions are grouped into a mob, (2) Mob Strategy Applied - when a strategy is assigned to a mob, (3) Target Selected - when a mob's strategy determines which target to attack, (4) Mob Action Executed - when all minions in a mob perform coordinated actions, (5) Mob Spawned - when a mob is created from a template or multiple actors, (6) Mob Edited - when mob composition or properties are modified, (7) Minion Added to Mob - when a minion is grouped into an existing mob, (8) Minion Removed from Mob - when a minion is ungrouped from a mob.
key_questions.What are the key business rules and cons: Business rules: (1) A mob must contain at least one minion, (2) All minions in a mob perform the same action when the mob acts, (3) Strategies determine target selection but must work within Foundry's combat and range rules, (4) Target selection strategies must evaluate available targets based on strategy criteria (power level, health, damage status, leader status), (5) Movement and range constraints from Foundry system must be respected, (6) Area attacks must follow Foundry's area effect rules, (7) Mob actions must be executed through Foundry's combat system, (8) Mob templates can be used to spawn mobs with predefined configurations.
key_questions.What domain language do business experts: Domain language: Mob (collection of minions acting together), Minion (individual game entity/token), Strategy (behavioral rules for target selection and actions), Target Selection (choosing which entities to attack), Spawn (create mob from template or actors), Group/Ungroup (add/remove minions from mobs), Attack Most Powerful/Weakest/Most Damaged (specific target selection strategies), Defend Leader (protective strategy), Area Attack (attack affecting multiple targets in an area), Range (distance constraints for attacks and movement), Token (visual representation on tabletop), Actor (game entity in Foundry system).
